title: Luka Svetec
text:
Luka Svetec (8 October 1826 – 28 January 1921) was a <a href="Slovenes">Slovene</a> <a href="politician">politician</a>, <a href="lawyer">lawyer</a>, <a href="author">author</a> and <a href="philologist">philologist</a>. In the 1870s and 1880s, Svetec was one of the most influential leaders of the so-called <a href="Old%20Slovenes">Old Slovenes</a>, a <a href="national%20conservative">national conservative</a> political group in 19th century <a href="Slovene%20Lands">Slovene Lands</a>. He was renowned as an honest and principled politician, and was praised for his decency and his straightforward, practical attitude to political questions and life in general. The Old Slovene leader <a href="Janez%20Bleiweis">Janez Bleiweis</a> called him "a crystallized Slovene common sense". Because of his failure to take over the political leadership of the party after the death of its leader Janez Bleiweis, also called <a href="Father%20of%20the%20Nation">Father of the Nation</a>, Svetec was mockingly referred in the press to as "Stepfather of the Nation".
Life and career.
Svetec was born in the <a href="Upper%20Carniola">Upper Carniola</a>n village of <a href="Podgorje%2C%20Kamnik">Podgorje</a> near <a href="Kamnik">Kamnik</a>, in what was then the <a href="Austrian%20Empire">Austrian Empire</a> (now in <a href="Slovenia">Slovenia</a>). After finishing the grammar school in <a href="Ljubljana">Ljubljana</a>, he enrolled at the <a href="University%20of%20Vienna">University of Vienna</a>, where he studied <a href="law">law</a>. After graduation in 1853, he worked in the Austrian administration in <a href="Croatia">Croatia</a>. After 1861, he returned to his native <a href="Carniola">Carniola</a>, at first as a senior official in the Austrian judicial administration in <a href="Mokronog-Trebelno">Mokronog</a> and <a href="Ko%C4%8Devje">Kočevje</a>, and subsequently as a district judge in <a href="Brdo%20pri%20Lukovici">Brdo</a>. Between 1866 and 1871, he worked in the municipal administration in Ljubljana, and later as a <a href="civil%20law%20notary">civil law notary</a> in <a href="Idrija">Idrija</a> and <a href="Litija">Litija</a>.
He participated in the <a href="Slovene%20national%20movement">Slovene national movement</a> since 1848. He was very active in the discussions on the creation of a <a href="standard%20language">literary standard</a> for the <a href="Slovene%20language">Slovene language</a>. He was one of the most vocal defendants of Slovene linguistic and national individuality against <a href="pan-Slavism">pan-Slavism</a> and <a href="Yugoslavia">Yugoslav</a>ism. He entered active politics in 1862, when he was elected to the <a href="provincial%20diet">provincial diet</a> of <a href="Carniola">Carniola</a>. In the 1870s, especially after the death of <a href="Lovro%20Toman">Lovro Toman</a>, he emerged as one of the most influential leaders of the <a href="Old%20Slovene">Old Slovene</a> political movement. Against the pragmatism of most of its leaders, Svetec called for an intransigent political action, thus frequently siding with the radical <a href="Young%20Slovenes">Young Slovenes</a>. Throughout his life, he defended the idea of <a href="United%20Slovenia">United Slovenia</a>. He opposed national demands based on historical state rights, and firmly supported the idea of <a href="natural%20right">natural right</a> of peoples.
After 1881, he was designated as the successor of <a href="Janez%20Bleiweis">Janez Bleiweis</a> as the leader of the Old Slovene movement. However, his leadership was rejected by the more conservative factions in the movement. After the mid-1880s, Svetec grew closer to the Slovene <a href="liberal%20nationalist">liberal nationalist</a>s, and finally joined the <a href="National%20Progressive%20Party%20%28Slovenia%29">National Progressive Party</a>.
He died at the age of 94 in <a href="Litija">Litija</a>.
